title: 108_s768
content: The "Senior Executive Service Reform Act of 2003" is cited in Section 1. Section 2 amends the locality pay adjustment limitation in title 5, United States Code. Section 3 addresses rates of pay for the Senior Executive Service. The Senior Executive Service Reform Act of 2003 amends Chapter 53 of title 5, United States Code to establish a range of rates of basic pay for the Senior Executive Service based on individual performance and contribution to the agency's performance. The lowest rate cannot be less than the minimum rate of basic pay, and the highest rate cannot exceed the rate for level III of the Executive Schedule. Comparability payments may be added to the highest rate. The payment of rates under this section is not subject to pay limitations of section 5306(e) or 5373. Technical and Conforming Amendments are made to the table of sections for chapter 53 of title 5, United States Code. Establishment of rates of pay for the Senior Executive Service is amended to set and adjust pay within a specified range. Limitations on pay fixed by administrative actions are also addressed in the amendments to Chapter 53 of title 5, United States Code. The amendments to Chapter 53 of title 5, United States Code include changes to section 5306(e) and section 5373(a) regarding pay rates for the Senior Executive Service. Section 5306(e) now excludes authorities under section 5376 or 5382, while section 5373(a) no longer includes paragraph (4) but references sections 4802, 5376, or 5382. SEC. 4. Rates of pay for administrative law judges are amended to level III, with the possibility of receiving comparability payments in addition to the highest rate. SEC. 5. Rates of pay for contract appeals board members are also amended to level III, with the option of receiving comparability payments in addition to the rates under subsection (b). SEC. 6. Rates of pay for certain senior level positions are addressed. SEC. 6 amends rates of pay for certain senior level positions to level III and allows for comparability payments in addition to the highest rate. SEC. 7 expands senior executive service limited appointment authority. The amendment expands senior executive service limited appointment authority by defining 'limited appointee' and 'career reserved position'. The amendment expands senior executive service limited appointment authority by defining 'limited appointee' and 'career reserved position'. Section 3394 of title 5, United States Code, is amended to read as follows: "Sec. 3394. Noncareer and limited appointments". The United States Code is amended to include provisions for noncareer and limited appointments to Senior Executive Service positions. Limited appointees must meet position qualifications and receive approval from the Office of Personnel Management. The duration of a limited appointment varies based on the position's duties, with potential extensions authorized in rare circumstances. Limited appointees to Senior Executive Service positions can be appointed for up to 2 years under subsection (c)(1) and up to 12 months under subsection (c)(2). They have reemployment rights in the agency they were appointed from or in another agency as directed by the Office of Personnel Management. Reassignment and transfer of limited appointees are governed by section 3395 of title 5, United States Code. Limited appointees to Senior Executive Service positions can serve for up to 4 years or less, with a possible extension approved by the Office. They can also be reassigned to another position within the agency for up to 12 months, with a maximum of 7 consecutive years under any combination of limited appointments. SEC. 8. ANNUAL LEAVE ENHANCEMENTS. Amends Section 6303(a) of title 5, United States Code to provide additional annual leave for certain employees. SEC. 9. EFFECTIVE DATE. The Act will take effect 90 days after enactment.
